issue.title: request and info are undefined in `Deno.serve` when using rest parameters

commits.message:
fix(ext/http): patch regression in variadic args to serve handler (#20796)

I'm not sure what was the purpose of trying to be so clever with the
args were (maybe an optimization?), but it breaks variadic args as
pointed out in #20054.

Signed-off-by: Matt Mastracci <matthew@mastracci.com>
Co-authored-by: Matt Mastracci <matthew@mastracci.com>

issue.title: stacktrace is affected by an eval statement just existing later in the script
issue.body:
run this code:
```
(function hello() {
  console.log('outer stack', new Error().stack)
})();

eval("")
```

Expected Output:
```
outer stack Error
    at hello (file:///....ts:2:30)
    at file:///....ts:3:2
```

Actual Output:
```
outer stack Error
    at hello1 (file:///....ts:2:30)
    at file:///....ts:3:2
```

stacktrace should have function "hello" but instead has "hello1". 


If you remove the eval statement, then the stack trace becomes the expected output.
Deno Version:
```
$ deno --version
deno 1.37.1 (release, x86_64-apple-darwin)
v8 11.8.172.6
typescript 5.2.2
```

Me reproducing the issue in a deno terminal:

https://github.com/denoland/deno/assets/1850562/0a9e0250-a355-4000-97dc-0d8dcca7db39

issue.title: Awful VSCode Deno plugin experience
issue.body: Hey! I wanted to report some isusses i've been having with deno VScode plugin experience. Goal of the ticket isn't to moan, or to repair the issues for me(unless its an obvious mistake on my side) but to just raise a flag to an issue with deno experience for new devs to the deno world :) ## Rough summary * deno plugin very slow to update types whenever i'm making code changes. I'd estimate regular delays of 5 seconds. I'm use to using 'normal' typescript in vscode, so i'm comparing it to that. * deno plugin 'crashing' when i use 'const type' for function parameters (eg `const f = (a: A) => {}`) * deno plugin just giving all my code 'any' types until i restart the plugin using the vscode command 'Deno: Restart Language Server' and then the types are good/accurate again. this happens multiple times an hour * deno plugin giving the wrong types(or more likely out of date types) until i restart the deno plugin. I might be a tad dramatic, but these issues have caused quite a few thoughts like "is deno worth the pain whilst building my library". ## A little context * the library i'm working on where i've had these issues https://github.com/jbsiddall/hubmodel (enrichment branch). Two possible issues in this library that could antognaise the deno language server: It has codegen that produces about 3500 lines of typescript that the rest of the coebase uses, and all the types in this library definitely lean heavy on the type system with some very big/deep types. * working on an intel macbook pro 16" 2019 with 32gb ram. * not using docker or any VM to run vscode * used nix to install deno. * in vscode deno plugin settings the setting "Deno: TS Server Memory" set to 3072. on process on my laptop is using more than 1GB, majority less than 250mb, so seems unlikely that its running out of memory. * deno version: ``` $ deno --version deno 1.37.1 (release, x86_64-apple-darwin) v8 11.8.172.6 typescript 5.2.2 ``` * deno vscode plugin version: 3.26.0 * vscode version: ``` Version: 1.83.1 (Universal) Commit: f1b07bd25dfad64b0167beb15359ae573aecd2cc Date: 2023-10-10T23:46:55.789Z (2 wks ago) Electron: 25.8.4 ElectronBuildId: 24154031 Chromium: 114.0.5735.289 Node.js: 18.15.0 V8: 11.4.183.29-electron.0 OS: Darwin x64 23.0.0 ``` * vscode installed plugins: * language server processes: ``` $ ps aux | grep -i deno joseph 99257 0.1 0.4 1211064304 263788 ?? S 7:22PM 1:41.80 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Code Helper (Plugin).app/Contents/MacOS/Code Helper (Plugin) --ms-enable-electron-run-as-node --max-old-space-size=3072 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js --useInferredProjectPerProjectRoot --enableTelemetry --cancellationPipeName /var/folders/j1/s91rs2r523gdwcl_3w3ztzr80000gn/T/vscode-typescript501/0b85b8d7462b74e36144/tscancellation-365f394b51d7b643bd6a.tmp* --globalPlugins typescript-deno-plugin,@twind/typescript-plugin --pluginProbeLocations /Users/joseph/.vscode/extensions/denoland.vscode-deno-3.26.0,/Users/joseph/.vscode/extensions/sastan.twind-intellisense-0.2.1 --locale en --noGetErrOnBackgroundUpdate --validateDefaultNpmLocation --useNodeIpc joseph 99258 0.0 3.0 38644368 2016908 ?? S 7:22PM 0:23.38 /Users/joseph/.nix-profile/bin/deno lsp joseph 99256 0.0 0.2 1211033524 125208 ?? S 7:22PM 0:44.86 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Code Helper (Plugin).app/Contents/MacOS/Code Helper (Plugin) --ms-enable-electron-run-as-node --max-old-space-size=3072 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js --serverMode partialSemantic --useInferredProjectPerProjectRoot --disableAutomaticTypingAcquisition --cancellationPipeName /var/folders/j1/s91rs2r523gdwcl_3w3ztzr80000gn/T/vscode-typescript501/0b85b8d7462b74e36144/tscancellation-a2fe3ffd07e0d2a31fcc.tmp* --globalPlugins typescript-deno-plugin,@twind/typescript-plugin --pluginProbeLocations /Users/joseph/.vscode/extensions/denoland.vscode-deno-3.26.0,/Users/joseph/.vscode/extensions/sastan.twind-intellisense-0.2.1 --locale en --noGetErrOnBackgroundUpdate --validateDefaultNpmLocation --useNodeIpc ``` If i'm organised enough to get some screen recordings of actual issues, i'll post them as comments. Thanks Guys! [edited] Context: on macos Sonoma 14.0 (23A344)

comment.body:
and just to add some extra context:
after adding a setting of `"deno.disablePaths": ["npm"]`, and deleting the npm directory for good measure, the deno process is now at 2GB memory not 3GB. My takeaway here is as users we have some control over bloating memory usage, and can use the vscode command "Deno: Language Server Status" to spot any extra unexpected files getting loaded in that we can prune. Combined this with the upping the memory limits of the deno process from 3GB to 10GB in my case, i suspect the crashing will no longer happen.

issue.title: ☂️ Node/npm compatibility issue for Q4 2023
issue.body:
This is an umbrella issue for Node.js/npm compatibility work that we will undertake in Q4 2023.

We made a lot of progress in Q2 with polyfills for `node:http`, `node:https` and `node:http2` getting more coverage, but there's still a lot of work to do.

There are several areas that we intend to improve this quarter:

- [ ] "Bring your own node_modules" (BYONM) - Deno should be able to work on projects with "node_modules" directory already installed by a 3rd party tool (npm, yarn, pnpm). 

This should lower the barrier of entry to try existing projects using Deno and should fix a lot of compatibility issues from various build tools that we're experiencing at the moment (eg. Vite). 

This work is well underway and is tracked in https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/18967.

- [ ] npm lifecycle scripts - there are many packages that use native addons (Node-API) that have either `preinstall`, `install` or `postinstall` scripts. 

Currently these scripts are ignored by Deno which causes certain packages to fail, even though they could work without a problem in Deno (eg. `sharp` fails when imported, but that's only because of the `postinstall` script not being run). We do not intend to arbitrarily run these scripts like npm does, but instead are working on an interactive solution, that would allow users to opt-in into these scripts (potentially running in a sandboxed Deno process) or ignore them altogether. 

The work on this has started, but will take several patch releases to finalize. We're starting with warnings, informing users that these scripts are currently not supported and might require manual interventation. 

This is tracked in https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/16164.

- [ ] Make more popular packages work - this is very open-ended, but so far we agreed to work on a list prepared by @birkskyum (thank you!) that cover quite a few high profile packages - https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/created_by/birkskyum. `grpc-js/grpc` and `google-cloud/datastore` are also targeted to be supported.

This requires polyfilling more APIs from `node:` builtin modules (you can see the current compatibility list at https://docs.deno.com/runtime/manual/node/compatibility). 

- [ ] Support for [npm workspaces](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v7/using-npm/workspaces) - required to run monorepos locally. We are still discussing this item as workspaces are specific to the package manager used - ie. npm workspaces work differently than yarn workspaces that work differently than pnpm workspaces. 

This issue will be updated, if we identify more areas we want to improve.

comment.body: Adding support for private npm registries would also be crucial for us. Issues are https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/20195 and https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/19900

issue.body: Hey! I wanted to report some isusses i've been having with deno VScode plugin experience. Goal of the ticket isn't to moan, or to repair the issues for me(unless its an obvious mistake on my side) but to just raise a flag to an issue with deno experience for new devs to the deno world :) ## Rough summary * deno plugin very slow to update types whenever i'm making code changes. I'd estimate regular delays of 5 seconds. I'm use to using 'normal' typescript in vscode, so i'm comparing it to that. * deno plugin 'crashing' when i use 'const type' for function parameters (eg `const f = (a: A) => {}`) * deno plugin just giving all my code 'any' types until i restart the plugin using the vscode command 'Deno: Restart Language Server' and then the types are good/accurate again. this happens multiple times an hour * deno plugin giving the wrong types(or more likely out of date types) until i restart the deno plugin. Two possible issues in this library that could antognaise the deno language server: It has codegen that produces about 3500 lines of typescript that the rest of the coebase uses, and all the types in this library definitely lean heavy on the type system with some very big/deep types. * working on an intel macbook pro 16" 2019 with 32gb ram. * not using docker or any VM to run vscode * used nix to install deno. * in vscode deno plugin settings the setting "Deno: TS Server Memory" set to 3072. on process on my laptop is using more than 1GB, majority less than 250mb, so seems unlikely that its running out of memory. * deno version: ``` $ deno --version deno 1.37.1 (release, x86_64-apple-darwin) v8 11.8.172.6 typescript 5.2.2 ``` * deno vscode plugin version: 3.26.0 * vscode version: ``` Version: 1.83.1 (Universal) Commit: f1b07bd25dfad64b0167beb15359ae573aecd2cc Date: 2023-10-10T23:46:55.789Z (2 wks ago) Electron: 25.8.4 ElectronBuildId: 24154031 Chromium: 114.0.5735.289 Node.js: 18.15.0 V8: 11.4.183.29-electron.0 OS: Darwin x64 23.0.0 ``` * vscode installed plugins: * language server processes: ``` $ ps aux | grep -i deno joseph 99257 0.1 0.4 1211064304 263788 ?? comment.body:
Hey Hey Hey,
Great news, the deno.disablePaths has massively dropped memory usage. Looks like this was user error(me) :) I'll quickly restore my normal stance of Deno VS plugin rocks! :P 

thanks @nayeemrmn @bartlomieju @cknight .

Can we close this ticket?

issue.title: Deno task `cp` wildcard does not work correctly
issue.body:
Hey, I want to recursively copy all `.html` files from `./src/client/` to `./dist/`. For this I wanted to use the following task command: ``` cp -r ./src/client/**/*.html ./dist/ ``` This command should normally (in my opinion) copy all files ending with `.html` recursively to `./dist/`. However, only the first file ending with `.html` is copied to `./dist/`. Is this how it is meant to be?
**Short summary** - **Command used:** ``` cp -r ./src/client/**/*.html ./dist/ ``` - **Expected behavior:** All files ending with `.html` and located in `.src/client/` are copied to `./dist/` with the same folder structure. > [Deno Glob Expansion Reference](https://docs.deno.com/runtime/manual/tools/task_runner#glob-expansion) > ``` > # match .ts files in the current and descendant directories > echo **/*.ts > ``` - **Actual behavior:** Only the file which ends with `.html` and is in the first directory level will be copied to `./dist/`.

issue.title: Fetch returns: Error trying to connect: Connection reset by peer (os error 54)
issue.body:
`let a = await fetch('https://pictures.vwe.nl');
console.log(a)`

Returns "Error trying to connect: Connection reset by peer (os error 54)"

`deno --version`
- deno 1.0.5
- v8 8.4.300
- typescript 3.9.2

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,97 +0,0 @@
-// Copyright 2018-2023 the Deno authors. All rights reserved. MIT license.
comment.body: I think this file should be kept in the same place as `remote.rs`. Currently the `remote` backend still lives in the Deno repo, but the datapath proto lives in `denokv`.

pull_request.title: chore: update ext/kv to use denokv_* crates
pull_request.body:
This commit updates the ext/kv module to use the denokv_* crates for
the protocol and the sqlite backend. This also fixes a couple of bugs in
the sqlite backend, and updates versionstamps to be updated less
linearly.

commits.message:
feat(doc): display non-exported types referenced in exported types (#20990)

Upgrades to deno_doc 0.70 which includes the feature for showing
non-exported types referenced in exported types as well as a much more
advanced deno doc that uses a symbol graph.

a deno module into an npm package.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -543,12 +580,37 @@ async fn call_remote<
       .post(&full_url)
       .header("x-transaction-domain-id", metadata.database_id.to_string())
       .header("authorization", format!("Bearer {}", metadata.token))
+      .header("x-watch", if streaming { "1" } else { "0" })
comment.body: This controls the *shape* of the response (streaming vs oneoff) rather than the *content*, and we want middleboxes (if any) to be able to look at it.
